Award.AwardTitle: Exact solvability of the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang stochastic partial differential equation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Kardar-Parisi-Zhang (KPZ) equation is a non-linear stochastic partial differential equation whose statistical properties are believed to describe a large class of mathematical models including interacting particle systems, random growth models, directed polymers, and branching diffusion processes. The purpose of this project is to make significant progress towards developing a theory of the exact solvability of the KPZ equation. In particular, this theory should lead to exact formulas for the probability distributions of the solution to the KPZ equation when started with various important types of initial data. This project will involve a number of fields of mathematics and this direction has already produced results of independent interest to these fields, which include: Macdonald symmetric function theory, tropical combinatorics and Whittaker functions, and certain quantum integrable systems.

Since its discovery two hundred years ago the Gaussian distribution (bell curve) has come to represent one of mathematics greatest societal and scientific contributions ? a robust theory explaining and analyzing much of the randomness inherent in the world. Physical and mathematical systems accurately described in terms of Gaussian statistics are said to be in the Gaussian universality class. This class, however, is not all encompassing. For example, classical extreme value statistics or Poisson statistics better capture the randomness and severity of events ranging from natural disasters to emergency room visits. More recently, significant research efforts have been focused on understanding systems which are not well-described in terms of any of the classically developed statistics. The failure of these systems to conform to classical descriptions is generally due to a non-linear relationship between natural observables and underlying sources of random inputs and noise. A variety of models for complex systems such as growth processes, polymer chains, mass transport, traffic flow, queueing theory, driven gases, and turbulence have been actively studied for over forty years in mathematics, physics, material science, chemistry and biology. All of these systems fail to conform with classical Gaussian statistics, as has been observed through experimental evidence involving turbulent liquid crystals, crystal growth on a thin film, facet boundaries, bacteria colony growth, paper wetting, crack formation, and burning fronts. Surprisingly, despite their differences, all of the systems fall into a new statistical universality class whose properties are described in terms of a single model called the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang (KPZ) equation. The purpose of this project is to develop a statistical understand of the KPZ equation and its universality class.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Partial differential equations (PDEs) are the basic mathematical models for describing systems in which future evolution is determined by the present state of the system nearby. Many of these systems are inherently non-linear so that doubling the input does not result in doubling the output, and many evolve subject to random (or stochastic) external influences. Therefore, the study of non-linear stochastic PDEs has become of central interest within science and mathematics. Two complementary goals in studying these equations are to understand properties of their solutions while also showing how they arise from (and hence describe) microscopic systems. This NSF project made breakthroughs in each of these goals for the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang (KPZ) equation – a non-linear stochastic PDE which has been extensively studied within physics and mathematics.

The KPZ equation was introduced in 1986 as a model for random interface growth (e.g. the boundary of a growing bacterial colony) and has since been connected with and applied to many other types of systems including traffic, flocks, crack formation, percolation and mass transport in random media. The PI and collaborators were responsible for the first exact solution to the KPZ equation whereby the statistical distribution for the random interface was computed along with its long-time/large-scale limit. This, in fact, was the first instance of a non-linear stochastic PDE which was ever solved in this manner. The long-time/large-scale limiting statistical distribution is conjectured to be a sort of modern day bell-curve – a universal limit for the behavior of a large class of different microscopic systems. As part of this NSF project, the PI and collaborators discovered and analyzed a wide variety of probabilistic systems and showed that they are described by the KPZ equation or its long-time/large-scale limit. Many of these advances relied upon the development (by the PI and collaborators) of a new subfield of probability called “Integrable Probability”.

Integrable probability seeks to build bridges between certain algebraic structures within mathematics and domains of physics and probability so as to discover and precisely describe universal phenomena. As part of this NSF project, the PI and collaborators introduced the theory of Macdonald processes and the theory of stochastic quantum integrable systems.

Representation theory provides elegant machinery to manipulate symmetries. Macdonald symmetric functions are a high point of this theory, unifying many seemingly disjoint types of symmetries. The theory of Macdonald processes similarly united a variety of systems within probability, statistical mechanics and mathematical physics such as random interface growth, interacting particle systems, directed polymer models, random tilings and random matrices.

Quantum mechanics of many-body systems is described by PDEs with inter-particle interactions. Solving this type of PDE is hard, but quantum integrable systems have interactions which factorized in a certain sense and allow explicit solutions. These special systems are built from solutions to the Yang-Baxter equation. Stochastic quantum integrable systems leverages this structure and implements it in the context of probabilistic systems. It provides an umbrella theory for exact calculation of the behavior of a variety of new and existing systems (many related to the KPZ equation).

Besides deep intellectual merit, this NSF proposal led to significant broader impacts. The PI organized a semester program at the Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics in winter 2016 (on the subject of this project) which involved approximately 100 mathematicians and physicists coming together.
